subject: RE: [junit] A test to verify that an event is generated
msgSnippet: ... No value judgment implied. :) ... I don t suppose it matters much, but no, I wouldn t call that a mock . It s just an implementation of the abstract
messageBody:
>So said Kris Henderson on 4/18/2003 --------------------
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>> That's an interesting approach. It's slightly different from
>> what I would do.
>
> Interesting in a good way? :)

No value judgment implied. :)

>> Why a MockService? Is the service not the thing you're
>> testing?
>
>The reason I created a MockService class is because I wanted to test the
>code in the abstract class and to get an instance of the abstract class
>I need a concrete class. Is a mock object the correct terminology in
>this case?

I don't suppose it matters much, but no, I wouldn't call that a "mock". It's just an implementation of the abstract class.

>> I always get nervous when I have to mock the thing
>> I'm testing. Since you're testing the event source, I would
>> recommend rewriting this test so that the event source you
>> test is an actual event source, and not some subclass
>> (however trivial) of it.
>
>The original intent of my test was to verify that an event is fired when
>certain methods in the abstract class are called and that the event
>object contained the correct data. Would that be considered testing the
>event source?

Yes, but...

>> For example: factor out the event source from the abstract
>> class, then test the event source on its own.
>
>I like this idea. I'll have to take a look at the design to see how I
>can work it in.

... this is the approach I would take.

Take care.
